head.p: This catalogue covers Albums A.27-32 from the Stein Collection. These albums are from Stein's Second Expedition, 1906-08. (Second series, large prints.) The series comprises six uniform grey cloth covered albums each measuring 245x307 mm, with prints inserted in aperture mounts, with openings of 152x107mm. The numbering runs sequentially through the whole series of albums as follows:

'So my ride to Mastuj on May 11th gave ample chance for collecting useful information. The morning hours were spent in taking copies and photographs of a Sanskrit inscription and a rock-carved Stupa representation closely resembling those of Pakhturinidini. The large boulder on which both are engraved was brought to light in a field near Charrun only some eight years ago...' Ruins of Desert Cathay, vol. 1, p. 44. PUBLISHED: 'Serindia', I, fig. 6, 'Boulder with representation of stupa and inscription near Charrun, Mastuj.'

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol 1, fig. 18: 'Bahadur khan, Governor of Mastuj, seated in centre with his two sons; Khan Sahib Pir Bakhsh on his right, and Mastuji attendants'. 'At the bridge leading back to the left bank old Bahadur Khan, the actual ruler of Mastuj and a cousin of the Chitral chief, awaited me in person with two youthful sons. Though close on eighty years, the portly white-haired chief seemed still full of vigour and genuine enjoyment of life and its pleasures...His straightforward, simple ways, full of old-fashioned courtesy withal, have made him a favourite with all European officials in Chitral' ('Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol 1, p. 46).
North-West Frontier Province; Pakistan; Tirich Mir

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 20: 'Parlour in Obaidullah's house, Miragram. Ceiling with sky-light of characteristic construction; below this, open fire-place; carpets of local make.' The interior ('modest rubble-built hovel as it looked from the outside, within proved a museum of local architectural ornament and household art') is described in more detail on p. 48. 'Serindia', I, fig. 16, 'Stateroom in Obaidullah Khan's house, Miragram.'

PUBLISHED: Prints 29-31 form the 'Panoramic view of the Darkot and Chatiboi Glaciers taken from the foot of the Rukang Spur, looking south and south-west' (Ruins of Desert Cathay, vol. 1, p. 54). The whole panorama is described as follows: 'On left [print 29] is seen the Darkot Glacier over which the ascent to the Darkot Pass ([marked] A) leads. The summit of the pass (i. p. 58) is hidden by the spur on extreme left. In middle [print 30] the Chatiboi Glacier with its highest position known as Kalandar-ghum ([marked] B; see i. p. 61). On the right of the Chatiboi Glacier high spurs ([marked] C) descending from Koyo-zum Peak (22,603 feet). On extreme right [print 31] snowy spurs ([marked] D) towards Tui Peak (21,891 feet). 'Serindia', I, fig. 20, 'View of Darkot Glacier from foot of Rukang Spur, looking south.'

Group of Shirin-dil Khan and officers, posed in front of felt tent: '...I was soon met on my way by gallant old Colonel Shirin-dil Khan, who, mounted on a fine Badakhshi and in full uniform, had galloped ahead with a crowd of horsemen to receive me. He had been sent up from Badakhshan by Prince Nasrullah, brother of the Amir and General Commanding in the Oxus Provinces, to assure my safe passage through the Afghan territory on the Pamirs. After patiently waiting for me at Sarhad for over four weeks he now offered me the warmest of welcomes...' (Ruins of Desert Cathay, vol. 1, p. 65). Also in the group is Hakim Mansur Khan, Governor of Upper Wakhan.

msItem.title: N. XLI Pan., Niya site. I.

note.p: PUBLISHED: Prints 93-96 form a 'Panoramic view taken near southern end of Niya site showing remains of ancient dwelling (A), tank with surrounding arbour (B), and footbridge (C) stretched across dry river-bed, all abandoned during the third century A.D.' Inserted in 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, p. 296. Additional descriptive text reads: 'The panorama was taken from the top of a tamarisk-covered sand-cone, and extends from S.E. (left) to W. (right). In the foreground behind the ruined dwelling (N. XLI., A) and tank (see i. pp. 295 sqq.) are seen the remains of dead trees and fences marking lines of ancient avenues and gardens. The figure of a man near ancient bridge (C) indicates the height of trestles still upright. Beyond left bank of dry river-bed are the remains of dead orchards (D) near what appears to have been a large reservoir. In near background, to south and south-west, chains of tamarisk cones; high ridges of dunes in distance.' Prints 93-96 also form 'Serindia', I, fig. 75, with caption similar to above.

Prints 289-292 form four sections (first section on left, presumably print 288, is missing) of a five-part panorama, entitled 'Panoramic view taken from crest of watershed above Huo-ning-to Pass, showing portions of the Richtofen, To-lai-shan and Alexander III ranges of Nai-shan'. PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, p. 314. The explanatory text continues: 'The panorama was taken at an elevation of circ. 15,500 feet to the north-west of the pass, which itself is hidden by rocky foreground (D; see ii. pp. 314 sqq. and Map III). The view extends from the north-east (left) to the south-west (right); the entries above the panorama indicate only the approximate bearings. It shows portions of the Richtofen Range west (A) and east (B) of Hung-shui-pa Ho, rising to peaks of over 18,000 feet. The high peaks of the To-lai-shan Range, over which the pass leads, are masked by neighbouring ridges (C) [print 289]. Across the wide valley of the Pei-ta Ho are seen in the distance the Uge-shan group (E) [print 290], rising to close on 19,000 feet, and other snowy portions of the Alexander III Range (F to H) [prints 291-292]. The approximate position of the pass by which we crossed this range is indicated by (G) [extreme right of print 291]. For a view from the same point to the north-west see Fig. 237 [Photo 392/26 (388)].' Stein describes the taking of this view on p. 315: 'The atmosphere was delightfully clear, and with the pleasure of getting this chance for a photographic panorama I scarcely noticed the icy wind which played over our narrow arête. So wild was the confusion of its fissured rocks that to keep the camera secure and take exposures all round cost much trouble. So when the work was accomplished I was glad to hurry down to the pass which our baggage train had just crossed in safety...'

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 296: 'My companions and myself at Ulugh-mazar, in the desert north of Chira. From left to right, sitting: Chiang-ssu-yeh, myself with 'Dash', Rai Bahadur Lal Singh. Standing: Ibrahim Beg, Jasvant Singh, Naik Ram Singh.' 'Serindia', III, fig. 320, 'Group of my party taken at Ulugh-mazar. From left to right: Ibrahim Beg; Chiang Ssu-yeh; self with 'Dash II'; Jasvant Singh; Rai Bahadur Lal Singh; Naik Ram Singh. Dead tamarisk cone in background.' This is one of the best portraits of Stein with his assistants in the collection.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 146: 'Portion of fresco frieze and dado on south-east wall of rotunda in Buddhist shrine M. V., Miran site. The frieze shows Prince Vessantara with his wife and children leaving the palace gate (p. 490). In the dado below are seen a girl playing the mandoline, a garland-carrying figure, and part of a bearded male bust.' For close view of lower half, see print 516 and 517.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 147: 'Portion of fresco frieze and dado on south wall of rotunda in Buddhist ahrine M. V., Miran site. The frieze represents Prince Vessantara making an offering of the magical white elephant (pp. 487, 490). In the dado the bust of an Indian prince between two garland-carrying Putti. Inch-measure on right below.' For close view of lower half, see print 518.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 96: 'Kharoshthi documents on double-wedge tablets from Ruin N. XIII., Niya site. Scale, three-sevenths. A. Reverse of complete double wedge tablet with fastening intact. B. Double wdge tablet opened after cutting string passed under clay seal. C. Obverse of double-wedge tablet retaining seal and string intact.'
Similar view of same seal seal as in print 543.

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 143: 'Fresco piece from frieze of ruined Buddhist shrine M. III., Miran site. The piece, originally found in several fragments, represents Gautama Bodhisattva in teaching pose, with princely worshipper. Painted on background of Pompeian red.'

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, col. pl. V: 'Portion of fresco composition showing scene from Buddhist legend; from frieze of ruined Buddhist shrine M. III., excavated at Miran site. (Chap. XLII: scale one-fifth [in published version]).'

msItem.title: M. V. fresco [of winged figure, from Miran site].
M. Misc. [Miscellaneous objects from Miran site.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 138: 'Remains of scale armour and miscellaneous objects found in Tibetan fort, Miran. Scale, two-sevenths [in published version]. 24, 26, a, b, c. Scales of lacquered leather from suits of armour, the last two showing method of lacing outside and inside. 25. Horn combs. 27. Felt pouch. 28, 29. Chinese copper coins of T'ang period. 30. Shaft of arrow. 31. Wooden key.'

msItem.title: Stone implements from Lop-nor and camps.
Stone implements from Lop-nor and camps.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 117: 'Small antiques, mainly in metal, collected from wind-eroded ground at Lop-nor site. Scale, two-sevenths [in published version]. 1. Wooden comb. 2. Signet ring in bronze. 3, 4, 21. Fragments of bronze mirrors with relievo decoration. 5, 8, 19. Metal clasps. 6, 11, 16. Decorated metal objects of uncertain use. 7. Small bronze bell. 9. Ivory die. 10. Fragment of bronze buckle, perhaps intended for cloisonné work. 12-15. Copper coins of Han period. 17, 18. Bronze arrow-heads. 20, 22. Lignite seals. 23. Lamp in burnt clay.'

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 116: 'Remains of ancient woven fabric from Lop-nor site. Scale, one-third [in published version]. Hemp show from ruin L.A. VI. 2. Slipper from L.B. IV., in wool material, woven in coloured pattern. 3. Small table of ancient silk (see p. 381). 4. Fragment of pile carpet in wool from L.A. 1.'

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 122: 'pieces of architectural wood-carving decorated in Gandhara style, from ruined Buddhist shrine, Lop-nor site. Scale, one-thirteenth [in published version]. 1, 5-7, 10. Ornamental beams and posts. 2. Balusters supporting small double brackets. 3. Panel with decayed relievo representation of seated Buddhas. 4. Large rosette filled with lotus. 8. Fragment of geometrical trellis work. 9 Portion of ornamental door frame.'

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, 173: 'Ancient implements and articles of equipment, excavated mainly from ruined watch-stations of early Chinese border line, Tun-huang. Scale, one-fifth [in published version]. 1. Ornamented wooden tent-peg. 2. Foot-measure with decimal division into inches. 3. Wooden fire-stick. 4. Polished wood handle. 5. Ivory-topped head of baton. 6, 7. Spatulas. 8. Carved wooden hooks (see. p. 95). 9. Bowl of lacquered wood...'

msItem.title: [Pottery, metal implements, etc., excavated from ruined watchtowers on Dunhuang limes.]

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 172: 'Ancient pottery and implements excavated from ruined watch-stations on Tun-huang limes. Scale, one-fifth [in published version]. 1. Wooden beating stick. 2. Broomstick of reeds. 3. Iron hoe. 4. Wedge of wood inscribed with two Chinese characters. 5. Pottery jar. 6. Broken piece of pottery mended with leather thong passed through holes.'

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 1, pl. 174: 'Ancient implements and articles of equipment, excavated mainly from ruined watch-stations of early Chinese border line, Tun-huang. Scale, one-fifth [in published version]...17. Carved wooden hooks (see. p. 95)....10. Hemp shoe. 11. Wooden key. 12, 20. Parts of wooden locks. 13. Wooden boot-last. 14. Fragment of calcined reed fascine (see p. 110). 15. Wooden socket for attaching seal. 16. Bronze arrow-head. 18. Block of wood for holding tapers. 19. Wooden eating-bowl.'

msItem.title: Misc. wood carvings & stucco relievo from sites of Ming-oi, '1000 Buddhas' & Tun-huang limes.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 273: 'Miscellaneous wood-carvings and stucco relievo from sites of 'Ming-oi', Khora, 'Thousand Buddhas,' and Tun-huang limes. Scale, one-third [in published version]. 1. Floral ornament in wood, 'Ming-oi'. 2. Grotesque relievo in wood, from painted panel, Khora. 3. Buddha image in wood, 'Thousand Buddhas'. 4. Stucco heads from Trimurti image, T. XXIV., Tun-huang limes. 5. Miniature stupa in wood, 'Ming-oi'. 6. Relievo in Gandhara style from wooden casket, 'Ming-oi'. 7. Grotesque wood-carving, 'Ming-oi'.'
China; Dunhuang; Dunhuang Limes; Gansu; Ming-oi; Xinjiang

PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 270: 'Stucco heads, showing Graeco-Buddhist art influence, from ruined shrines, 'Ming-oi' site, Kara-shahr. Scale, one-third [in published version]. 1. Bearded head of classical type with Indian head-dress. 2, 3. Grotesque heads. 4. Shrouded head. 5. Grotesque head, derived from Gorgo on miniature shield (see ii, p. 368). 6, 9. Heads, probably of Bodhisattvas. 7. Head of Naga type. 8. Satyr-like head.'

msItem.title: Gigantic roll of paper, with Sanskrit and 'unknown language' texts in Brahmin script, walled-up temple library, Tun-huang.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 193: 'Gigantic roll of paper, with Sanskrit and 'unknown language' texts in Brahmi script, from walled-up temple library, 'Thousand Buddhas,' Tun-huang. Scale, one-fifth [in published version]. A. shows the roll, which is over seventy feet long, partially opened. B. [see print 567a] shows the silk painting on top of outer side.' Prints 567-567a have been joined to form this illustration.

note.p: The terracotta tile also appears in print 571. PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 274: 'Relievo tile in terracotta and miniature shields in stucco from ruined shrines, 'Ming-oi' site, Kara-shahr. Scale, three-tenths [in published version]. 8. Miniature shield with wooden stick supporting it. 9. Grotersque head on shield, from Gorgo model. 10. Tile showing head of Buddha divinity.

msItem.title: Old Chinese mss. & blockprints from walled-up temple library of '1000 Buddhas' site, Dunhuang.

note.p: PUBLISHED: 'Ruins of Desert Cathay', vol. 2, pl. 191: 'Old Chinese manuscripts and blockprints from walled-up temple library of 'Thousand Buddhas' site. Scale, one-fifth [in published version]. 1. Complete Buddhist manuscript roll, T'ang period. 2, 3. Manuscripts of religious texts in book form. 4. Booklet made up of ink rubbings from inscriptions. 5. Block-printed sheet with Buddhist picture and prayer. 6. Roll of block-printed Buddhist text with frontispiece from wood-engraving, dated 864 A.D.'
